snippet: A four-year, $43 million program is being welcomed in Vietnam, but many people say the effort is too little and too late.
abstract: United States begins historic clean-up project to rid Vietnam of dioxin, chemical contaminant in Agent Orange, used as a defoliant during the Vietnam War, that has been linked to cancers, birth defects and other diseases; many in Vietnam appreciate the program, which is expected to cost $43 million and take four years to complete, but say effort is too little and too late.
lead_paragraph: A four-year, $43 million program is being welcomed in Vietnam, but many people say the effort is too little and too late.

headline.seo: U.S. Moves to Address Agent Orange Contamination in Vietnam
headline.main: 4 Decades on, U.S. Starts Cleanup of Agent Orange in Vietnam
headline.print_headline: 4 Decades On, U.S. Starts Cleanup Of Agent Orange in Vietnam
